4.1 A Case of Political Argumentation by Reciting Poems

With the preliminary knowledge about cultural background being laid out, in this section we are going to focus our attention on the political argumentation by reciting poems. We will follow the procedure to analyze a case of this kind of argumentation. From step 2 (of localized procedure), the case to be analyzed is introduced in detail in Sect. 4.1. As stipulated by step 3, the rules governing argumentation are recognized in Sects. 4.2–4.4. In Sect. 4.5, we follow step 4 to justify the rules discovered in the last step. Through steps 1–4, we can find out locally rational rules and demonstrate how this procedure works. In Sect. 4.6, we will test the argumentative rules with a new case briefly (step 5). Now we will present a particular case.

①In autumn, in the 7th month, the marquis of Qi and the earl of Zheng went to Jin in the interest of the Duke Xian of Wei. Duke Ping of Jin entertained them at the same time, and recited the Jia Le (Kew loh). ②Guo Jing-zi was in attendance on the marquis of Qi, and recited the Lu Xiao (Luh seaou).③ Zizhan was in attendance on the earl of Zheng, and recited the Zi Yi (Tsze-e). ④Shuxiang instructed Duke Ping to acknowledge [the compliment paid by] the two princes, and then said, “My ruler ventures to thank the ruler of Qi for the rest which he secures to the ancestral tablets of our former princes. He ventures also to thank the ruler of Zheng for his unswerving adherence.” ⑤Guo Jing-zi makes Yan Ping-zhong say privately to Shuxiang, “The ruler of Jin displays his brilliant virtue to the States, compassionating their distresses, repairing their defects, correcting their errors, and relieving their troubles. In this way he is the lord of covenants; but how is it that he has now in the behalf of a subject seized the ruler?” Shuxiang told this to Zhao Wen-zi, who reported it to Duke Ping. ⑥Duke Ping explained to him the offence of Duke Xian of Wei, and made Shuxiang inform the two princes of it. ⑦Guo Jing-zi on this recited the Pei Zhi Rou Yi (Pe che jow), and ⑧Zizhan recited the Qiang Zhong Zi Xi (Tseang Chung-tsze he). ⑨After this Duke Ping granted the return of Duke Xian to Wei. (Adapted from the Zuo Zhuan, Duke Xiang 26th year, Legge 1991a, p. 525)Footnote 7

Before analyzing the text move by move, let’s see the social setting of the case. In Duke Xiang 14th year (559 BC), Duke Xian of Wei (ruler of the state of Wei) had been banished by Sun Lin-fu and Ning Hui-zi, two of his cabinet officials, and later they (the latter two) enthroned marquis Shang in the same year. In Duke Xiang 26th year (547 BC), Ning Xi, son of Ning Hui-zi, killed marquis Shang and attacked Sun clan and succeeded in restoring Duke Xian to power in Wei. Sun Lin-fu, who had surrendered himself to Duke Ping of Jin, the leader of the alliance, requested Jin to come to his rescue. Jin went to help Sun Lin-fu. In its military campaign against Sun, Wei killed three hundred soldiers. This irritated Jin and Jin gathered all the member states of the alliance to discuss a military campaign against Wei. Duke Xian went to Jin to seek a peace deal but was detained by Jin. The marquis of Qi and the earl of Zheng hurried to Jin to request the release of Duke Xian.

For convenience of analysis, we put numbers ①–⑨ before each move of argumentative exchange and divide them into three rounds. Round one includes ①–④, round two ⑤–⑥ and round three ⑦–⑨. Besides, we adopt a simplified upper capitals with numerals to designate characters involved in the case. All the characters are to be divided into two argumentative parties: J party and W party. Here it is:

J Party: J 11 (Duke Ping); J 12 (Zhao Wen-zi); J 13 (Shuxiang)

W Party: W 11 (marquis of Qi); W 12 (Guo Jing-zi); W 13 (Yan Ping-zhong) W 21 (the earl of Zheng); W 22 (Zizhan)

4.2 Round One

①In autumn, in the 7th month, the marquis of Qi (W 11 ) and the earl of Zheng (W 21 ) went to Jin in the interest of the Duke Xian of Wei. Duke Ping of Jin entertained them at the same time, and recited the Jia Le.

W 11 and W 21 (members) went to Jin in order to seek the release of Duke Xian. Having known the purpose of their visit (Zeng 1993, p. 279), J 11 (the leader) feasted the two visiting noblemen with a banquet. In this context, there arose a demand for J 11 to carry out the welcome (function) and this welcome was carried out by way of reciting Jia Le. This poem has four stanzas and previous studies have shown that J 11 took meaning of the first stanza of the poem (Zeng 1993, pp. 119–120, 279):

Of [our] admirable, amiable, sovereign (假乐君子)

Most illustrious is the excellent virtue (显显令德).

He orders rightly the people, orders rightly the officers (宜民宜人)

And receives his dignity from heaven (受禄于天)

Which protects and helps him, and [confirms] his appointment (保右命之)

By repeated acts of renewal from heaven (自天申之). (Legge 1991b, p. 481)

This piece of discourse is being used to speak highly of the sovereign, or to perform “praise” (function). In this particular context of the banquet, J 11 (the leader) compared the two noblemen to the sovereign in the poem so as to compliment them. By doing so, this stanza is intended to be a welcome to W party. In this move, the function rule of ① is: in the context of an official meeting (at a banquet) between members and the leader of an alliance, the leader is supposed to welcome the visitors; the expression rule of ① is: in the context of an official meeting (at a banquet) between members and the leader of an alliance, reciting a poem with complimentary content can be used to realize the function of welcome.

②Guo Jing-zi (W 12 ) was in attendance on the marquis of Qi (W 11 ), and recited the Lu Xiao.

After J party’s recitation, W 12 understood the poem by the first stanza and took it as a welcome. Having received the welcome, in return W 12 (the member) expressed his gratitude (function) for the welcome and further made a request (function) for the release of Duke Xian since this was the purpose of visit. This was performed by W 12 ’s reciting Lu Xiao. The poem has four stanzas and previous studies found that the meaning of the first stanza of the poem was taken (Zeng 1993, pp. 276–277, 279):

How long grows the southernwood (蓼彼萧斯),

With the dew lying on it so bright (零露湑兮)!

Now that I see my noble men (既见君子),

My heart is entirely satisfied (我心写兮).

As we feast, we laugh and talk (燕笑语兮);

It is right he should have fame and prosperity!(是以有誉处兮) (Legge 1991b, p. 274)

This stanza begins with a depiction of southernwood, capturing the moment when the dew was lying in the southernwood. With the nurturing from the dew, the southernwood grows long! In this particular context that a welcome from J 11 (the leader) had been extended, the members of an alliance benefit from the grace of the alliance leader just like growth of the southernwood benefits from the nurturing of the dew. Since for W party, the purpose was to seek the release of Duke Xian and the latter was also one of the members, therefore, the grace of J 11 should likewise reach him, thus proffering a request (Zeng 1993, p. 279). The context comprehension rule of ② is: at the banquet, alliance members could choose the first stanza for understanding in relation to the poem recited by the alliance leader; the function rule of ② is: in the context that a welcome is initiated by way of reciting a poem by the leader at a banquet, and considering the purpose of visit, the members could choose to express thanks as a response; the function of request could be indirectly performed; the expression rule of ② is: in the context that a welcome is initiated by way of reciting a poem by the leader at a banquet, and considering the purpose of visit, reciting a poem with appreciative content can be used to realize the function of thanking and indirect request.

③Zizhan (W 22 ) was in attendance on the earl of Zheng (W 21 ), and recited the Zi Yi.

After J party’s recitation, W 22 (the member) understood the poem by the first stanza and took it as a welcome as W 12 did. Having received the welcome and followed W 12 , in reply to J 11 (the leader),W 22 expressed his loyalty (function) to Jin and further made a request (function) for the release of Duke Xian since this was the purpose of visit. These two functions were realized through W 22 reciting Zi Yi. This poem has three stanzas and former studies have found that the meaning of the first stanza was employed (Zeng 1993, pp. 277, 279):

How well do the black robes befit you (缁衣之宜兮)!

When worn out, we will make others for you (敝,予又改为兮).

We will go to your court (适子之馆兮),

And when we return [from it], we will send you a feast (还,予授子之粲兮)! (Legge 1991b, p. 124)

This stanza describes the devotion and loyalty of a wife to her husband. In this particular context that a welcome from J 11 had been extended, W 22 adopted this meaning of the poem to express the members’ loyalty to Jin by comparing their loyalty to that of a wife to her husband. Since for W party, the purpose was to seek the release of Duke Xian, and the latter, being among the members, was also loyal, therefore W 22 intended to make a request for the release of the detainee. In this move, the context comprehension rule of ③ is: at the banquet, alliance members could choose the first stanza for understanding in relation to the poem recited by the alliance leader; the function rule of ③ is: in the context that a welcome is initiated by way of reciting a poem by the leader at the banquet, and considering the purpose of visit, the members could choose to declare loyalty to the leader and thus make a request; the expression rule of ③ is: in the context that a welcome is initiated by way of reciting a poem by the leader at the banquet, and considering the purpose of visit, the members could recite a poem with loyalty-expressing content to declare loyalty and make an indirect request.

④Shuxiang (J 13 ) instructed Duke Ping (J 11 ) to acknowledge [the compliment paid by] the two princes, and then said, “My ruler ventures to thank the ruler of Qi for the rest which he secures to the ancestral tablets of our former princes. He ventures also to thank the ruler of Zheng for his unswerving adherence”.

After W 12 and W 22 recited Lu Xiao and Zi Yi respectively, considering these poems being used as responses to Jia Le recited by J 11 together with the purpose of visit, J party took what had been expressed in the first stanzas of the recited poems as requesting the release of Duke Xian by way of expressing gratitude and declaring loyalty respectively by the two visitors.So, J 13 led J 11 (the leader) to express thanks to W 11 and W 21 (the members). In the reply to W 11 who recited the first stanza of Lu Xiao to express thanks to J 11 and to make a request for Duke Xian’s release, J 11 expressed the gratitude (function) toward W 11 with regard to the thanks expressed, by taking the meaning of the first stanza of this poem but did not mention the release of Duke Xian to W 11 (cf. Yang 1990, pp. 1116–1117; Zeng 1993, pp. 279–280). In the reply to W 21 who recited the first stanza of Zi Yi to show their loyalty and to make a request for Duke Xian’s release, J 11 expressed the gratitude (function) toward W 21 for the loyalty by taking the meaning of the first stanza of this poem with regard to the loyalty expressed but did not mention the release of the detained duke to W 21 (ibid.). By this way of replying, J 11 intimated a decline of the requests indirectly proffered by the two dukes (function). In this move, the context comprehension rule of ④ is: in responding to the poems recited by the alliance members, the alliance leader could choose to understand the poems by taking the first stanzas and the linguistic context as well as the purpose of alliance members; the function rule of ④ is: in the context that the members express thanks, loyalty and indirect request by reciting two poems and considering the purpose of visit at a banquet, the leader could use the function of thanking and indirect declining; and the expression rule of ④ is: in the context that the members express thanks, loyalty and indirect request by reciting two poems and considering the purpose of visit at a banquet, in line with the contents of the poems recited, the leader could use plain language to directly express the function of thanking, and avoid mentioning relevant event to decline the request.

4.3 Round Two

⑤Guo Jing-zi (W 12 ) makes Yan Ping-zhong (W 13 ) say privately to Shuxiang (J 13 ), “The ruler of Jin (J 11 ) displays his brilliant virtue to the States, compassionating their distresses, repairing their defects, correcting their errors, and relieving their troubles. In this way he is the lord of covenants; but how is it that he has now in the behalf of a subject seized the ruler?” Shuxiang (J 13 ) told this to Zhao Wen-zi (J 12 ), who reported it to Duke Ping (J 11 ).

After J 11 expressed thanks to W party and did not mention the release of Duke Xian, considering that J party knew W party’s purpose of seeking the release of Duke Xian, W 12 and W 13 understood what J party had said as declining their request. With such a context that J 11 (the leader) did not directly mention the release, W 12 (the member) proceeded with a questioning (function) considering that their purpose of visit was to seek the release of Duke Xian. This questioning was performed by an overt verbal expression. In expressing, W 12 brought up the responsibilities for a leader (compassionating their distresses, repairing their defects, correcting their errors, and relieving their troubles) and pointed out that helping Sun Lin-fu (cf. Sect. 4.1), Duke Xian’s subject, to imprison the duke was in violation of the responsibilities of a leader. J 13 told this to J 12 and the latter told this to J 11 . Here is the context comprehension rule of ⑤ is: when one party makes a request and the other party, in responding, does not mention things related to the request, the latter could be understood as declining the request; the function rule of ⑤: in the context of an indirect decline from the leader and considering the purpose of visit, members could choose a questioning function; the expression rule of ⑤ is: in response to the indirect decline, members could choose the norm concerning the leadership to directly express the questioning.

⑥Duke Ping (J 11 ) explained to him the offence of Duke Xian of Wei, and made Shuxiang (J 13 ) inform the two princes of it.

After W 13 questioned Duke Ping of Jin’s helping Duke Xian’s subject to hold Duke Xian as hostage in violation of the responsibilities of an alliance leader, considering that Jin was the alliance leader and that W party came for the release of Duke Xian, J 11 understood what J 13 said directly as requesting the release of the detainee. After the revelation of the purpose of visit and the questioning from W 13 (the member), J 11 (the leader) now tried to defend himself for imprisoning Duke Xian, explaining that it was not about Duke Xian being sent into exile but about Duke Xian having committed a crime in the first place (cf. Legge 1991a, p. 525). In so doing, J 11 rebuked the questioning by W 13 . Here, the context comprehension rule of ⑥ is: based on the purpose of requesting, when a verbal questioning is put forth one party, the other party could understand the questioning as asking for the acceptance of the request; the function rule of ⑥ is: in the context that the leader is questioned by an overt expression, the leader chooses to defend; the expression rule of ⑥: in the context that the leader is questioned by an overt expression, an overt explanation of reasons can be used.

4.4 Round Three

⑦Guo Jing-zi (W 12 ) on this recited the Pei Zhi Rou Yi.

After J party’s justification for keeping Duke Xian in response to the questioning made by W 13 (namely, telling W party about the reason of keeping Duke Xian), W 12 understood that J party intended the decline the request. Having been informed of the reason about the detention of Duke Xian, that is, Duke Xian perpetrated a crime in the first place. With the aim to having Duke Xian released, W 12 (the member) made a remonstrance and persistent request (function) and this is done by reciting Pei Zhi Rou Yi, not denying that Duke Xian had committed the crime. The complete version of this poem is lost and what remains available now are the three verses. It reads:

Be the horse strong, hold the bridle loose (马之刚矣,辔之柔矣);

Be the horse not strong, hold the bridle tight (马亦不刚,辔亦不柔);

Have strong aspiration, do not hesitate (志气麃麃,取与不疑).

The short poem is used to describe the proper way to deal with the relation between the horse and the bridle. If the horse is strong, let the bridle loose up, and vice versa. In such a context, the way a leader treats the members (including Duke Xian) is likened to the way a loosened bridle goes with a strong horse (the first verse) (Zeng 1993, pp. 277–278, 280), which serves to remonstrate with J 11 (the leader) that he should be more lenient to the members, further intending it as an indirect request for the release. In this move, the context comprehension rule of ⑦ is: when the other party provides justification in response to one party’s questioning, the latter could understand the justification as declining; the function rule of ⑦ is: in the context that a rebuttal is brought forth at the banquet and considering the purpose of visit, the members could choose the function of positive remonstrance and direct request; the expression rule of ⑦ is: in the context that a rebuttal is brought forth at the banquet and considering the purpose of visit, reciting such a kind of exhortative poem can express the positive remonstrance and direct request.

⑧Zizhan (W 22 ) recited the Qiang Zhong Zi Xi.

After J party’s justification for keeping Duke Xian in response to the questioning made by W 13 (namely, telling W party about the reason of keeping Duke Xian), W 22 understood that J party intended the decline the request. So, this last attempt shares the same context and function with that of ⑦ and this is done by reciting Qiang Zhong Zi Xi. It has three stanzas and previous studies found that the meaning of last stanza of the poem was adopted (Zeng 1993, pp. 278–280):

I pray you, Mr. Zhong (将仲子兮),

Do not come leaping into my garden (无逾我园);

Do not break my sandal trees (无折我树檀).

Do I care for them?(岂敢爱之)

But I dread the talk of people (畏人之多言).

You, O Zhong, are to be loved (仲可怀也),

But the talk of people (人之多言),

Is also to be feared (亦可畏也). (Legge 1991b, p. 127)

It depicts the complex mental state of a lady who is in love with a man. She expects to meet him but at the same time she dreads the “talk of people”. She cares not about ruined trees in a secret date with Mr. Zhong, but she cares about people’s talk. Considering the context, people’s talk about Jin’s taking Duke Xian is compared to that about Mr. Zhong’s leaping into the garden/destroying the sandal tree (Zeng 1993, p. 280). By doing so, W 22 (the member) was remonstrating with J 11 (the leader) that people’s talk is to be feared, thus making a further request (function) for releasing Duke Xian. In this move, the context comprehension rule of ⑧ is: when the other party provides justification in response to one party’s questioning, the latter could understand the justification as declining; the function rule of ⑧ is: in the context that a rebuttal is brought forth at a banquet and considering the purpose of visit, the members could choose the function of negative remonstrance and direct request. The expression rule of ⑧ is: in the context that a rebuttal is brought forth at a banquet and considering the purpose of visit, members could recite exhortative poems to realize the function of negative remonstrance and direct request.

⑨After this Duke Ping granted the return of Duke Xian to Wei.

After W and W recited Pei Zhi Rou Yi and Qiang Zhong Zi Xi respectively, considering W party’s purpose of visit, J party took the implied meaning of Pei Zhi Rou Yi and the last stanza of Qiang Zhong Zi Xi, thinking that W 12 intended Pei Zhi Rou Yi to implicate that alliance leader should respect and care for the alliance members, and that W 22 intended Qiang Zhong Zi Xi to implicate that it would be censured that the alliance leader helps the subject of Wei to rebel against the ruler (Sun Lin-fu’s rebelling against Duke Xian). In the end, J 11 (the leader), having considered the attempts made by W 11 and W 21 (the members), conceded and promised to release Duke Xian. This concession, probably, was based on power reality of Jin, which was on the decline because Jin had just quelled a domestic riot and on the other hand Chu, Qin and Qi were seeing growth of power (cf. Ma 1992, pp. 280–294; Tong 2006, pp. 70–72, 75–76). Thus, the case is concluded with W party succeeding in persuading J party to release the detainee. Here from the text, we could not see the expression rule but could reveal the context comprehension rule of ⑨: in responding to poems recited by alliance members, the alliance leader could choose the implied meaning and last stanza in understanding the poems recited with the consideration of purpose of the alliance members and linguistic context; and the function rule of ⑨: in the context that a reasonable remonstrance is made and some other factors are considered, the leader chooses to accept the opponents’ request.

In summary, the sequence of 9 discourses (in the form of poem or verbal articulation) in this case constitutes the whole argumentation process which could be divided into four argumentation stage according to such a proposed division rule: argumentative sequence could be compartmentalized based on regular conversation turn construction, normal developments of social actions and cultural scripts etc.

Argumentation stage 1 (①–④): W party indirectly requested J party to release Duke Xian but did not succeed so as to make clear the standpoint of J.

Argumentation stage 2 (⑤–⑥): W party questioned J party directly and obtained the reason why J party didn’t want to release Duke Xian.

Argumentation stage 3 (⑦–⑧): W party requested J party again to release Duke Xian, not denying the reason provided by J party. W party still stuck to the belief that J party had violated the alliance leader norm.

Argumentation stage 4 (⑨): J party accepted W party’s request to release Duke Xian, thus concluding the argumentation.

4.5 The Reasonableness of the Rules of Political Argumentation by Reciting Poems

Up to now, we have elaborated in detail a case of political argumentation of reciting poems. Through such a detailed elaboration, we have found the context comprehension rules, function rules and expression rules for the argumentative move in the whole course of this argumentation. Now, we are going to justify these rules and explain their reasonableness in the social cultural context. Because the same social norms may support different rules and one rule may be supported by different norms, for the sake of convenience, the rules supported by the same norms will be chunked into one group and then be justified.

We have one group of context comprehension rules that we could find particular in Chinese ancient culture. The context comprehension rules of ② ③ ④ ⑨ conform to the norm of reciting and understanding poems. As introduced, it works as follows: first, take part or the whole of the poems when reciting; take part or whole of the poems when understanding; second, when understanding the poems, take what is expressed or what is implied through the poems (see Sect. 3.3). The context comprehension rules used in ⑤ ⑥ ⑦ ⑧, however, tend to show little cultural tendency, which means that they could be found in different cultures.

We have three groups of function rules. Firstly, the function rule of ① is in line with the alliance leader norm that leaders should respect the members of the alliance. Secondly, the function rules of ② ③ ④ ⑨ comply with the poem-replying norm (cf. Sect.3.3) which requires that when one party recites poems in line with Li, the other party is supposed to reply according to the poem.

Thirdly, the function rules of ② ③ ⑤ ⑦ ⑧ conform with the alliance member norm that when the ruler (or the leader) commits some mistakes, the subjects (or the officials) should make remonstrance, which is a kind of social norm in the Spring and Autumn Period. There were specific institutions about remonstrance in that time. For example, in the Zuo Zhuan, Duke Xiang 14th year, the music-master Kuang of Jin said “Heaven, in giving birth to the people, appointed for them rulers to act as their superintendents and pastors, so that they should not lose their proper nature. For the rulers there are assigned their assistants to act as tutors and guardians to them, so that they should not go beyond their proper limits. Therefore the son of Heaven has his dukes, princes of states have their high ministers; ministers have [the heads of] their collateral families; great officers have the members of the secondary branches of their families… These stimulate and honour those [to whom they stand in such a relation], when they are good, and correct them when they do wrong” (Legge 1991a, p. 466). In our case, ② ③ ⑤ ⑦ ⑧ show that when the leader (Duke Ping of Jin) committed mistakes (helping Sun Lin-fu, the subject of Duke Xian of Wei), the members (rulers of Qi and Zheng) should remonstrate with the leader.

We have four groups of expression rules. Firstly, the expression rules of ① ② ③ ⑦ ⑧, which deal with the realization of certain functions by reciting poems, comply with norms of reciting poems (cf. Sect. 3.3) at banquets in the Spring and Autumn Period. Because poems were classics in that period and had become the common discourse between dignitaries, people (dignitaries) could use poems to express their ideas, especially at banquets. As a matter of fact, poem-reciting activities in the Spring and Autumn Period mainly took place at banquets. For instance, in the Zuo Zhuan, the poem-reciting activity appears 34 times among which it happened at banquets 22 times and therefore “it is part of the feast ritual” (Ding 2006, p. 115).

Secondly, the expression rules of ② ③ ④ ⑦ comply with the alliance leader norm (cf. Sect. 3.2) that the leader of the alliance should respect and care for the allies.

Thirdly, the expression rule of ③ meets the alliance member norm (cf. Sect. 3.2) that the members should be subservient to the leader (loyalty declaring being a form of subservience).

Finally, the expression rules of ⑤ ⑥ ⑧ accord with the alliance leader norm (cf. Sect. 3.2) that the leader should fight the members who have violated the principle of Li(礼), as is recorded in Duke Xiang 11th year “All we who have covenanted together [are here] because your great state found it necessary to punish a small one which had offended”(Legge 1991a, p. 453).

After the rules we obtained from the case analysis are justified, they are recognized as adequate social norms for argumentation making. In the following part, on the basis of the analysis above, we are going to describe argumentation as a language game with discourse governed by social norms. In the process, motivated by the initial context of discourse ①, the arguer 1 selects the function of discourse ① based on the function rule of discourse ①, and then produces discourse ① based on the expression rule of discourse ①. Finally, discourse ① produces new information and effect on the other arguer 2 ’s original context. At this moment the first move is over and the next move begins. Arguer 2 grasps the new context and the meaning of discourse ① according to context comprehension rule. In a similar way the following moves of this game are going on till the end. In light of the analysis offered in Sects. 4.2–4.4 and the explanations provided above, it becomes clear that political argumentation by reciting poems has the following features. First of all, the poems recited are authoritative. By authoritative it is meant that participants in the political argumentation by reciting poems will mutually acknowledge the authority of the poems they are reciting. Then, the method for reciting and understanding poems that is used in this kind of argument is as follows: the reciters select the poems, part or whole, to meet the demands of the situational context and to take the meanings in their best interest; and accordingly, the addressees of the poems understand the recited poems in the way that they select the possible meanings of the poems, part or whole, in their best interest. In the end, the whole process of the political argumentation by reciting poems take the principle of Li as the reasons to their standpoints, just as we have laid out in part 3 of this paper.

4.6 Test of Rules

Till now, we have analyzed a political argumentative case of the Spring and Autumn Period in which participants, mainly the alliance leader and members, use poems to make their arguments. The argumentative rules we obtained from analysis conform to the social norms of the Spring and Autumn Period. We get two main categories of norms: poem reciting norms and norms about relationships between alliance leader and members. These two kinds of norms also could be found in some other cases of the Spring and Autumn Period. Here in the following is a case that may help us to test the rules (step 5 of localized procedure).

In Duke Xiang 18th year (555 BC), the alliance leader Jin, together with some other alliance members like Lu and Wei launched an attack against Qi for the reason that Qi had encroached on Lu for many times. In Duke Xiang 19th year, marquis Ling of Qi died and Qi wanted to make peace with Jin. In this background, Lu was worried that Qi did not really mean to make peace with Jin and that Qi may continuing encroaching on Lu (cf. Zeng 1993, pp. 260–261). So Mushu, an official of Lu went to Jin and asked for help from Shuxiang:

Mushu had a meeting with Shuxiang, he recited the 4th stanza of the Zai Chi (Tsae ch’e). Shuxiang said, “I dare not but receive your command.” (Adapted from the Zuo Zhuan, Duke Xiang 19th year, Legge 1991a, p. 484)

The poem Zai Chi recited by Mushu has five stanzasFootnote 8 and the fourth stanza reads:

I would have gone through the country,

Amidst the wheat so luxuriant.

I would have carried the case before the great State.

On whom should I have relied? Who would come to the help of Wei? (Legge 1991b, p. 89)

Here Mushu took the alliance leader Jin as a reliable power and asked Jin to help Lu (the function) in order to save Lu from Qi’s encroachment. (cf. Zeng 1993, p. 260) The function rule is: in the context that the alliance members is under attack from other state, the member could ask for help from the alliance leader. This function rule accords with the alliance leader norm which stipulates that the leader should care for the member and protect the member from attacks. (cf. Sects. 3.2 and 4.5) The expression rule is: in the context that the alliance members is under attack from other state, the member could appeal to reciting poems to realize the request function. This rule conforms with the poem-reciting norm. (cf. Sects. 3.3 and 4.5)

Shuxiang knew that Qi didn’t really mean to make peace (cf. Zeng 1993, pp. 260–261). After Mushu recited the poem, Shuxiang also took the fourth stanza for understanding thinking that Mushu was asking Jin to help Lu and responded, in plain language, to the latter in agreement to the request. Here the context comprehension rule is: in responding to the fourth stanza of the poem recited by the alliance member, the leader could choose to the implied meaning of the recited stanza in understanding. This rule conforms to the poem-reciting norm we had laid out. (cf. Sects. 3.3 and 4.5) The function rule is: in the context that the alliance member asks for help by reciting poems, the alliance leader could choose to help the member. This rule accords with the poem-replying norm we laid out. (cf. Sects. 3.3 and 4.5) The expression rule is: in the context that the alliance member asks for help by reciting poems, the alliance leader could use plain language in answer to the poems recited and agree to the request for help to the alliance member. This rule conforms with the alliance leader norm we laid out. (cf. Sects. 3.3 and 4.5).

Apart from these two cases, there are many other cases of political argumentation by reciting poems in the Spring and Autumn Period that could be used to test these kinds of rules. For example, the Zuo Zhuan has it that in Duke Xiang 8th year (565 BC) Fan Xuan-zi of Jin recited Biao You Mei (P’eaou yew mei) to ask Lu to attack Zheng together with Jin and Ji Wu-zi of Lu agreed by reciting Jiao Gong (Keoh kung). There is another example. In Duke Xiang 16th year (557 BC) Mushu of Lu recited Qi Fu (K’e foo) in order to ask Zhongxing Xian-zi of Jin to rescue Lu and recited Hong Yan (Hung yen) to ask help from Fan Xuan-zi and both them agreed to help Lu at last.

4.7 Little Red Book Quotation Fight: A Similar Phenomenon

It’s clear that participants in the political argumentation by reciting poems in the Spring and Autumn Period recite poems from some authoritative and widely accepted texts (for example poems) and re-contextualize the meanings of the texts based on their original meanings to meet the contextual demands. By so doing, they reach their argumentative goals of persuading the other(s). In Chinese history, this kind of argument is not a rarity. Among others, the quotation from Little Red Book (also known as Quotations from Chairman Mao Zedong) in the Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution (1966AD–1976AD) is worthy of note.

In that period of time, almost everyone had one copy of the Little Red Book. Quotation from the Little Red Book is so commonly seen that even beggars, when begging, make use of the book to its fullest and quote such saying as “We came from all across the country and our common revolutionary goal has united us together… Among us, we should care for each other, love each other and help each other…” Afterwards, they stick out their hands (He 2012, p. 72). This shows that the beggar can persuade others to accept his position through quoting a political maxim from the Little Red Book.

In various ways of usage of the book, quotation fight is the most prominent form, in which two debating parties “fight” each other by plunging into the book and looking for the most appropriate and authoritative quotes to support their ideas and rebuke their opponents’ ideas. So, what concerns us here is that the quotation fight bears certain similarities to the political argumentation by reciting poems. In them, the participants on different sides resort to some other sources when expressing their ideas in argumentative activities. Here is an example.

The Spring and Autumn period (Chunqiu 春秋, 770-5th cent. BCE) is the first part of the so-called Eastern Zhou period (Dongzhou 東周, 770-221 BCE). It is characterized by a significant decrease of political power of the kings of Zhou which had to flee to the eastern capital Chengzhou 成周 (or Luoyi 雒邑, modern Luoyang 洛陽, Henan) after their western and main capital Zongzhou 宗周 (of Feng 豐, near modern Xi'an 西安, Shaanxi) had been attacked by the nomad tribes of the Quanrong 犬戎.

Periodization

The name of the historical period is derived from the chronicle of the regional state of Lu 魯 called Chunqiu 春秋 "Spring and Autumn Annals" because the seasons are always mentioned in the entries. The Annals cover the time from 722 to 481 BCE, yet the historical period is traditionally counted from the reign of King Ping of Zhou 周平王 (r. 770-720 BCE), who restored the Zhou dynasty in Luoyang, down to the division of the state of Jin 晉 by the regional rulers (zhuhou 諸侯) of Han 韓, Wei 魏 and Zhao 趙 in 376. Alternatively, the end of the Spring and Autumn period can be seen as 453, when the three viscounts (zi 子) of Han, Wei and Zhao extinguished all other lateral lines to the house of Jin, or 403, when King Weilie of Zhou 周威烈王 (r. 426-402) bestowed upon the viscounts of Han, Wei and Zhao the title of marquis (hou 侯).

The second great historiographical writing of the Spring and Autumn period is the collection Guoyu 國語 "Discourses of the states" that includes anecdotes of the states of Zhou 周, Lu 魯, Qi 齊, Jin 晉, Zheng 鄭, Chu 楚, Wu 吳 and Yue 越. Said to be a composition of Zuo Qiuming 左丘明, its oldest parts must have been compiled at the end of the 5th century BCE.

Confucius

The most important intellectual person of this historical period was the philosopher Confucius (Kongzi 孔子; ca. 551-479) who tried to revive the ideal of the human and righteous rulers of old. Although his ideas seemed lost in a time of political realism his thoughts about state and society ("Confucianism") were to become the fundamental doctrine of imperial China.

The Early Decades of the Eastern Zhou and the Duke of Zheng

The eastern capital Chengzhou (Luoyang) did not provide the kings of Zhou with sufficient power. They were therefore dependent on the powerful regional rulers, especially those of Qin 秦, Jin, Qi and Chu. These are called the "local rulers" (fang bo 方伯) because they practically ruled independently from the king of Zhou, and not any more as his vassals. It became common that the regional states acted on their own behalf regarding territory and military feuds, without asking the king of Zhou for formal permission. Duke Zhuang of Zheng 鄭莊公 (r. 743-701) even dared attacking King Huan 周桓王 (r. 720-697 BCE) who had not treated him properly according to the ritual regulations. Heijian 黑肩, the Duke of Zhou 周公, even planned to kill King Huan's successor, King Zhuang 周莊王 (r. 697-682), and to replace him with Prince Ke 克. Yet Xin Bo 辛伯 warned the king and saved his life.

Duke Zhuang of Zheng defeated intruding Rong 戎 tribes and swallowed the neighbouring state of Xu 許. In 707 King Huan of Zhou 周桓王 (r. 719-697) started a punitive expedition against the Duke, but the king was defeated. From then on, the kings of Zhou never again tried to intervene into the politics of their own regional rulers. They stayed in their small royal domain around Luoyang and had to be content with the tributes of the regional rulers that were presented less and less regularly. Besides Zheng, the states of Song 宋 and Lu 魯 demonstrated their military and political power in the Central Plain.

The Rise of Duke Huan of Qi

King Li 周釐王 (r. 682-677) was so helpless against the new threats endangering the empire that he allowed Duke Huan of Qi 齊桓公 (r. 685-643) to adopt the title of hegemonial lord (ba 霸, or bo 伯). In this function the Duke defended the regional states against raids of barbarian tribes and cared for law and order among the states of the Middle Kingdom, with the motto "support the king and ward off the barbarians" (zun wang rang yi 尊王攘夷).

In the east, the state of Qi had rich natural ressources and became one of the mightiest regional states of the Eastern Zhou period.

Duke Huan of Qi employed the legalist statesman Guan Zhong 管仲 as his adviser who reorganized administration and the military and financial systems. Through these reforms Qi was able to subdue Song and Lu and even the hegemonial state of Zheng. At that time, the non-Chinese nomad tribes of the Rong and Di 狄 undertook raids on the soil of Chinese states and devastated the states of Xing 邢 and Wei 衛 (modern Shanxi and Hebei). Duke Huan of Qi rescued the dynastic houses of these states and settled them down more to the south. The system of the hegemon thus developed to a kind of lord protector of a strong state over weaker ones, and Qi promised to protect the states in the Central Plain against further intrusions of the northern nomad warriors.

The Semi-Barbarian Kingdom of Chu

In the south, the state of Chu on the middle Yangtze River had become politically stronger than before. King Cheng of Chu 楚成王 (r. 671-626) started to challenge the hegemony of Qi and swallowed smaller states in his neighbourhood. Nonetheless, subservient states like Jiang 江 and Huang 黃 changed side and declared their alliance with Qi. Chu thereupon attacked Zheng. Duke Huan assembled the regional rulers and created an alliance with Lu, Song, Chen and Wei to punish Chu in 656 by devastating the state of Cai 蔡, an ally of Chu. Chu gave in, and the ambassadors of the two mighty states met at Shaoling 召陵 (modern Yancheng 郾城, Henan) to conclude a peaceful alliance (meng 盟).

The System of Hegemonial Lordship

In 651 Qi organized a meeting at Kuiqiu 葵丘 (modern Lankao 蘭考, Henan) whith the representatives of Lu, Song, Zheng and Wei, and in presence of a royal diplomat from Zhou. The members of the meeting decided that states creating a friendly alliance should never attack each other, and that they had to assist each other in case that one partner was attacked. The Duke of Qi thus became the overlord over the weaker states of Zhou China and replaced the king of Zhou as the highest judicial person.

Succession Crises at the Zhou Court

When King Li died a succession crisis endangered the house of Zhou. His righteous heir was Prince Kan 閬, who is known as King Hui 周惠王 (r. 677-652), but his late grandfather, King Zhuang, had had a favourite son called Prince Tui 穨. King Hui was not a very intelligent ruler. He offended many of his highest ministers and caused a rebellion that forced him to flee to Wen 溫 (modern Wenxian 溫縣, Henan) and then to Li 櫟, a town in the state of Zheng. His uncle Prince Tui was made King of Zhou, but he did not prove a better ruler. He was therefore attacked and killed by the lords of Zheng and Guo 虢. King Hui returned to the throne.

When King Hui died he was succeeded by his son Prince Zheng 鄭, who is known as King Xiang 周襄王 (r. 652-619). King Xiang had a half-brother called Shudai 叔帶 (or Dai 帶), who had been the favourite son of King Hui. Prince Shudai planned to usurp the throne and joined forces with the Rong and Di 翟 tribes. The plot failed and Prince Shudai fled to Qi. It was a high minister of Qi, the reformer Guan Zhong, who mediated the peace treaty between the house of Zhou and the Rong tribes. A decade later the king of Zhou even allowed Prince Shudai to return.

When the state of Zheng attacked in 639 the statelet of Hua 滑, whose lords were relatives to the house of Zhou, King Xiang sent You Sun 游孫 and Bo Fu 伯服 as diplomats to negotiate peace. Yet the Duke of Zheng arrested the diplomats. The King thereupon ordered the Di tribes to attack Zheng, inspite of the remonstances of minister Fu Chen 富辰. Fu Chen was also not content with the King's will to marry a Di princess in order to reward the Di chieftain for his support. His critics were justified because only a few years later King Xiang discarded the "barbarian" queen, which caused an attack of the Di on the royal capital, during which the Earl of Tan 譚 (or the earls of Yuan 原 and Mao 毛) was/were killed. Fu Chen thereupon threw himself into battle against the intruders and died. King Xiang fled to Zheng and was received by the duke of Zheng, in spite of all former discrepancies.

In the meantime Prince Dai was enthroned as King of Zhou, yet he took residence in Wen, not in Luoyang. He invited the Di queen to return to the royal domain. Two years later King Xiang asked the duke of Jin for help, who willingly attacked the usurper and executed him. King Xiang, returning to the throne, rewarded Duke Wen of Jin 晉文公 (r. 636-628) with the title of hegemonial lord and presented him with some territory. Duke Wen was thereafter the most powerful political leader of the Middle Kingdom and assembled the regional rulers, including his formal superior, the King of Zhou, at Heyang 河陽 and Jiantu 踐土. The kings of Zhou were now wholly dependent from support by other political actors. Histories nevertheless concealed this shameful situation with terms like "royal hunt at Heyang".

The Rise of the Regional State of Jin

After the death of Duke Huan of Qi several regional rulers strove for overlordship. Duke Xiang of Song 宋襄公 (r. 650-637) was defeated by Chu, and the state of Song lost its last chance to rise to political and military significance. Instead, the state of Jin rose to supremacy in old China: Duke Xian of Jin 晉獻公 (r. 676-651) had already extended the power of his state by swallowing the statelets of Geng 耿, Huo 霍, Wei 魏 (a state that was later one of the three destructors of Jin), Guo 虢 and Yu 虞. After a decade of inner struggles, the state of Qin supported Duke Wen of Jin in his ascension to the throne of Jin.

Just as Duke Huan of Qi, Duke Wen of Jin employed political advisors, Zhao Shuai 趙衰 (Zhao Chengzi 趙成子) and Hu Yan 狐偃, who strengthened the "national" economy and so the military power of the state. In 635 the King Xiang of Zhou escaped from inner disturbances to the state of Zheng. Duke Wen of Jin saw his chance, rescued the king and accompanied him back to the royal domain, for which support he was highly rewarded by the King.

The next step for the Duke was to challenge the power of the southern, semi-Chinese state of Chu that had dominated the Central Plain since the death of Duke Huan of Qi. In 632 the two states clashed at the battle of Chengpu 城濮 (modern Zhencheng 甄城, Shandong), and Chu was defeated. Duke Wen of Jin established a new friendly alliance during the meeting at Jiantu 踐土 (modern Yingze 滎澤, Henan) with the seven most important states. In the same year, at Wen, the King of Zhou sanctified the hegemony by Jin. Duke Wen's successor Duke Xiang 晉襄公 (r. 627-621) was able to prolong the hegemonial prevalence of the state of Jin.

Conflict Between Qin and Jin

During the reign of Duke Xiang of Jin, Duke Mu of Qin 秦穆公 (r. 659-621) opened a long period of military confrontation between Jin and Qin, but Qin seldomly won any battle. The powerful state of Jin blocked the gate to the Central Plain, and Qin could not but expand its territory to the west into the territory of the Western Rong tribes 西戎 and establish good relations with Chu in the south. Chu meanwhile further expanded its territory by conquering the statelets of Jiang 江, Lu 六 (a special reading!), and Liao 蓼. After the death of Duke Xiang of Jin, the noble Zhao Dun 趙盾 (Zhao Xuanzi 趙宣子) dominated the throne succession of Jin, murdered Duke Ling 晉靈公 (r. 620-607) and enthroned Duke Cheng 晉成公 (r. 606-600). During this period Jin lost its initiative in "foreign" politics. The political advisor Fan Shan 范山 proposed to King Mu of Chu 楚穆王 (r. 625-614) to take the chance and to advance against the north.

The Rise of the State of Chu

King Zhuang of Chu 楚莊王 (r. 613-591) had to resolve internal quarrels and uprisings of aboriginal tribes before he was able to reform economic and military administration and to resume this expansion politics. In 606 the southern king sent out an envoy to the court of King Ding of Zhou 周定王 (r. 606-586) to express his will to swallow the royal domain of Zhou. In 598 King Zhuang of Chu crushed the small state of Chen 陳, one year later the state of Zheng. At the battle of Bi 邲 (near modern Zhengzhou 鄭州, Henan) the army of the hegemonial state of Jin was defeated.

A few years later, Chu defeated the state of Song and finally obtained the overlordship over the Central Plain. The protecting task of the overlord had gradually lost its original intention and became a system of hegemony of one major state over weak satellites of Chinese and "barbarian" origin. The attitude to help small states during internal quarrels and against "barbarian" invaders changed to a regular intervention into political affairs to the advantage of the great states.

Internal Quarrels in Jin

The state of Qi observed the growing power of Chu, declared a friendly relationship with the southern king of Chu, who was the only regional ruler who called himself king, except, of course, the King of Zhou. Qi repeatedly attacked the smaller states of Lu and Wei which therefore asked for support the former hegemonial state of Jin. In 589, the army of Jin fought with Qi in the battle of An 鞍 (modern Jinan 濟南, Shandong) and once again demonstrated its superior military power. Chu instantly declared war to Jin, but neither Chu nor Jin dared to initiate a concrete campaign.

After long years of hesitation and negotiations (under the stipulation of Jin's political advisor Song Huayuan 宋華元) Chu attacked Zheng and Wei in 576. One year later the armies of the two hegemonial states fought in the famous battle of Yanling 鄢陵 (modern Yanling, Henan) in which Jin prevailed by a narrow margin. Duke Li of Jin 晉厲公 (r. 580-573) saw his chance to resume hegemony, murdered his mightiest noblemen Xi Zhi 郤至, Xi Qi 郤錡 and Xi Chou 郤犨 (the "Three Xi" 三郤). Yet instead of having strengthened his own position, Duke Li faced serious opposition by the Jin aristocracy like Luan Shu 欒書 and Xun Yan 荀偃 who eventually killed their lord.

Under the next ruler, Duke Dao 晉悼公 (r. 572-558), the internal situation calmed down, and the duke was able to strengthen the position of the state of Jin. His political advisor Wei Jiang 魏絳 proposed to appease the nomad warriors of the Rong with financial tributes instead of fighting them. In 571 Jin erected a fortification wall at Hulao 虎牢 (modern Fanshui 氾水, Henan) against the state of Zheng that was backed by Chu.

After more than two decades of relative peace the political advisor Song Xiangxu 宋向戌 proposed to organize a peace conference to end military conflict. It was held in the capital of Jin in 546 and the participating fourteeen states decided to accept the overlordship of the two states of Jin and Chu. Their adherents had to declare their subjection under the respective overlordship and to present tributes to the two hegemons. Among the participating states, there would be ten years of peace, and for more than fourty years, Jin and Chu would not meet at the battle field again.

Only two of the larger states did not participate in the general peace: Qi, and Qin.

The old kingdom of Zhou had totally lost its political role. The tributes once paid to the kings of Zhou were now offered to the dukes of Jin and the kings of Chu. If a small state did not pay tribute it had to expect military sanctions. Especially precarious was the role of the state of Lu that had to maintain good relationships to the three states of Jin, Chu and Qi, if it did not want to be swallowed by one of them. Very similar was the role of Zheng that was directly in the line of fire between Jin and Chu. But states like Lu also imitated the overlordship of their own masters and demanded tributes from yet smaller states like Teng 滕, Qi 杞 or Zeng 鄫.

The Rise of the Semi-Barbarian States of Wu and Yue

During the relatively peaceful sixth century, the two southern non-Chinese coastal states of Wu 吳 and Yue 越 emerged as new powers. Jin saw its chance to open a second flank against Chu, and in 583 Duke Wuchen of Shen 申公巫臣 was sent to Wu in order to seek a military alliance. The semi-barbarian state of Wu was equipped with military tools and Wu soldiers were trained to attack Chu. But it was only more than half a century later that Wu became a serious threat to Chu after swallowing the statelet of Xu 徐.

Under King Helü 闔閭 (r. 514-496) the political advisor Wu Yuan 伍員 proposed to raise three armies that clockwise were to skirmish at the borders of Chu to weaken this state. In 506 the whole army of Wu finally attacked Chu and defeated this state at Baiju or Boju 柏舉 (modern Macheng 麻城, Hubei). In pursuit of the escaping enemy, the army of Wu advanced to the capital of Chu, Yingdu 郢都 (modern Jiangling 江陵, Hebei). King Zhao of Chu 楚昭王 (r. 516-489) had to take his flight and sought for help in Qin. This western state sent out chariots that expelled the invaders from Wu.

Wu's neighbour Yue took the advantage of the prolonged campaigns against Chu to invade Wu. In 496, Wu set its troops into march to carry out a punitive expedition against Yue, but King Helü died in the battle of Zuili 檇李 (modern Jiaxing 嘉興, Zhejiang). Two years later, King Fucha 夫差 of Wu (r. 495-473) defeated Yue during the revenge battle of Fujiao 夫椒 (modern Suzhou 蘇州, Jiangsu). Goujian 句踐, king of Yue (r. 496-465), fled to Mount Guiji 會稽山 (south of modern Shaoxing 紹興, Zhejiang).

Although Fucha's advisor Wu Yuan proposed to destroy the state of Yue, the king of Wu was content with his success in battle and the destruction of the capital of Yue. After the defeat of Chu and Yue, King Fucha turned his attention to the north. He had a fortification wall built at Han 邗 (near modern Yangzhou 揚州, Jiangsu) and dug out canals (see Grand Canal) that connected the Yangtze River with the Huai River 淮水 valley, creating a traffic line to the north and the possibility to move troops faster. The small states of Lu and Zhu 邾 declared themselves subjects to Wu. In the years 485 and 484 Wu attacked several times the state of Qi by land and by river and finally defeated Qi in the battle of Ailing 艾陵 (modern Laiwu 萊蕪, Shandong). Wu assembled the states of the Central Plain to a meeting at Huangchi 黃池 (modern Fengqiu 封丘, Henan), with the intention to declare its hegemony. Jin, weakened by internal struggles, did not dare to challenge the new powerful state of Wu, and King Fucha became the new hegemon.

Just during the conference of Huangchi, King Goujian of Yue took the chance and invaded the capital of Wu. The overstretched military power of the state of Wu was unable to withstand the southern opponent who had rebuilt its strength after the defeat of Guiji. In 473, Yue destroyed the state of Wu and replaced it as the dominating power of the southeast. King Goujian of Yue was the last of the so-called Five Hegemons (Wuba 五霸).

The Five Hegemons are also called the "Five Earls" (Wubo 五伯). Different literary sources and commentaries identify them with different persons. The traditional definition by Zhao Qi 趙岐 defines them as Duke Huan of Qi, Duke Wen of Jin, Duke Mu of Qin, Duke Xiang of Song, and King Zhuang of Chu. The book Xunzi 荀子 identifies them with Duke Huan of Qi, Duke Wen of Jin, King Zhuang of Chu, King Helü of Wu and King Goujian of Yue.

The Disintegration of the Old Order of Regional States

In the mid-5th century BCE there were four states that dominated old China: Chu in the south, Yue in the southwest, Jin in the north, and Qi in the east. Yet things were to change soon: Inner conflicts toppled two of the reigning houses (Jin and Qi), new powers emerged (Wei 魏, Zhao 趙 and Han 韓), and reforms in the administration of several states created a new type of "modernized" regional state: the centralized state with a strengthened "national" economy and a professional army. The administration of the state by nobles related to the ruling house was replaced by a bureaucratic officialdom.

The state Lu was the first that felt the power of noble families which challenged the ducal house, in this case the Three Huan (Sanhuan 三桓, descendants of Duke Huan 魯桓公) the Jisun 季孫, Mengsun 孟孫 (Zhongsun 仲孫) and Shusun 叔孫. From the time of Duke Xi 魯僖公 (r. 659-627) on these three noble families dominated the state of Lu. Duke Zhao 魯昭公 (r. 541-510) even had to escape from their intrigues and died abroad. At the beginning of the fifth century minor nobles like Nan Kuai 南蒯, Yang Hu 陽虎 and Hou Fan 侯犯 rebelled against the mighty families and took over the rule of Lu.

Descendants of the dukes of Song fought for the domination within the small state: the families Hua 華, Yue 樂, Lao 老, Huang 皇 (descendants of Duke Dai 宋戴公, r. 799-766), Yu 魚, Dang 蕩, Lin 鱗 and Xiang 向 (descendants of Duke Huan 宋桓公, r. 681-651). In the permanent power struggles only the families Yue and Huang survived the Spring and Autumn period.

The seven descendant lineages of Duke Mu of Zheng 鄭穆公 (r. 627-606) also gradually lost their power in the course of the Spring and Autum period.

In the state of Qi, the government was led by the lineages of Guo 國, Gao 高, Cui 崔 and Qing 慶. In this state it was a family not related to the ducal house that took over power in Qi: the family Tian 田, descendants of a prince from Chen, Tian Jingzhong 田敬仲, who had come to Qi in 672 while escaping internal disturbances in Chen. Under Duke Jing 齊景公 (r. 547-490), Jingzhong's descendant Tian Qi 田乞 was ennobled and from this position collected wealth and power enough to annihilate the families Guo and Gao. His son Tian Chang 田常 was already wealthier than the Duke himself and sent his ambassadors to the neighbouring states. His descendants would eventually replace the reigning house in Qi.

The most tremendous power challenge from within took place in the state of Jin where descendants of the ducal line were not invested as regional governors (dafu 大夫). But this measure did not prevent other noble families from trying to dominate the court of Jin: Hu 狐, Zhao 趙, Xian 先, Xi 郤 and Xu 胥 were the dominating noble clans of the middle Spring and Autumn period, and were later replaced by the families Han 韓, Wei 魏, Luan 欒, Fan 范 and Xun 荀. At the beginning of the 5th century the noble families of Zhao, Wei, Han, Fan, Zhonghang 中行 and Zhi 智 survived the internal struggle. The three first could destroy the last three and dissolved the dukedom of Jin, dividing its territory among themselves.

During the reign of King Ding of Zhou 周定王 (r. 607-586), the southern ruler King Zhuang of Chu 楚莊王 (r. 613-591) advanced his armies as far as the valley of River Luo in the pursuit of the Rong tribes of Luhun 陸渾. The king of Chu used this situation pay the king of Zhou a visit, but King Ding only sent Prince Man 滿 ("Royal Grandson Man" 王孫滿) to confer with the semi-barbarian king of Chu. They talked about the so-called "nine tripods" (jiuding 九鼎) erected in the capital that symbolized the nine regions of the kingdom of Zhou.

After the death of King Ling of Zhou 周靈王 (r. 572-545) and during the reign of King Jing 周景王 (r. 545-521) a succession crisis beset the house of Zhou. The heir apparent, Prince Sheng 聖, had died prematurely. King Jing preferred his oldest son Prince Chao 朝, yet when the king died, Prince Gai 丐 was supported by a strong party among the courtiers. The highest ministers enthroned Prince Meng 猛, who was immediately attacked and killed by the adherents of Prince Chao. Prince Meng is posthumously known as King Dao 周悼王 (r. 521-520). Prince Chao proclaimed himself king of Zhou, yet Prince Gai on his side asked for support by the duke of Jin and finally made it to the throne. He is known as King Jing 周敬王 (r. 520-476). Prince Chao, who had reigned for four years, fled to Chu. In 504, when he had assembled a sufficient number of supporters, he attacked King Jing and forced him to flee to Jin. A year later Duke Ding of Jin 晉定公 (r. 512-475) helped King Jing back on the throne.

Zhuang of Chu died 621 BC.page_content:

King Zhuang of Chu (Chinese: 楚莊王; pinyin: Chǔ Zhuāng Wáng, died 591 BC) was a monarch of the Zhou Dynasty State of Chu during the Spring and Autumn Period of ancient Chinese. His personal name was Xiong Lü, ancestral name Mi (芈), and King Zhuang was his posthumous title. He became one of the Five Hegemons and attempted to wrest control of China from the king of Zhou.

King Zhuang ascended the throne in 613 BC at a time when the Kingdom of Chu was in disarray. For the first three years of his reign, Zhuang wasted time on excessive hunting and lavish partying. Several courtiers were anxious about the king but none dared speak up as he had given orders that anyone who challenged his authority would be killed. When a particularly senior minister challenged him through a riddle, the king responded that he had been waiting for three years for someone from his court to show some nationalistic pride.

The king made Sunshu Ao chancellor and began a series of reforms. Chu's agricultural output improved significantly during his reign, aided by Sunshu Ao's comprehensive dam-works and an enormous planned reservoir created in modern-day northern Anhui province. In 611 BC he annexed the State of Yong (庸国), a move which made Chu much stronger.

After some overwhelming victories at the head of his army, King Zhuang attempted to take the place of King Ding of Zhou. He asked a messenger from Zhou about the weight of the Nine Tripod Cauldrons which Zhou possessed, a euphemism for seeking ultimate power in China at the time but was rebuffed.

In the Battle of Bi, his army defeated the State of Jin, another strong state at that time. Later he achieved hegemony amongst some other states. His progress from lazy regent to a hegemon of his time gave rise to the Chinese Four-character idiom of yī mǐng jīng rén (Chinese: 一嗚驚人; literally: "Amaze [the others] with one cry").

King Zhuang of Chu (楚莊王) was one of the Five Hegemons of the Spring and Autumn Period (春秋五霸, 770-476 B.C.), and the most accomplished monarch of Chu.

At a celebration after the suppression of a rebellion, King Zhuang and his ministers drank to their heart’s content. King Zhuang had his concubine Xu Ji toast the ministers. In the evening, he ordered the court to light candles, and the singing and dancing continued.

Suddenly a gust of wind blew out the candles. In the darkness, one of the drunken courtiers pulled on Xu Ji’s clothing. In those days, no men were allowed in the palace unless they were castrated. Assaulting a concubine in this way was a serious offence. She pulled the tassel off of the courtier’s hat and asked King Zhuang to deal with him. King Zhuang not only did not do anything about it but also said loudly that everyone should take their tassels off, relax and enjoy. After all the ministers had taken off their tassels, King Zhuang ordered the candles to be relit.

Xu Ji was both surprised and angry. When the banquet was over, she complained to the king. He replied, “It is excusable to be careless after drinking. If I were to condemn a minister to death over something like this, it would chill the hearts of other ministers, and they would not be able to do their best to defend the country.” Nodding, Xu Ji listened, and agreed.

The minister was undoubtedly at fault for his drunken demeanor, but King Zhuang showed breadth of mind in the way he handled the incident. In time, he was repaid for his kindness.

When King Zhuang was leading his troops to attack the state of Zheng, he was ambushed, and in a critical situation. Tang Cui, the vice general of the Chu army, single-handedly rushed into the enemy lines and rescued King Zhuang from the chaos. The King of Chu was very grateful and wanted to reward him. Then Tang Cui told him that he was the one who had pulled on Xu Ji’s clothes at “the feast of the tassels.”

Later on, the story of “the Feast of the Tassels (絕纓之宴 Jué yīng zhī yàn)” was used as an allusion to treating people with generosity.

King Gong of Chu (Chinese: 楚共王 or 楚龔王; pinyin: Chŭ Gōng Wáng, 600–560 BC) was from 590 to 560 BC the king of Chu, a major power during the Spring and Autumn period of ancient China. He was born Xiong Shen (Chinese: 熊審), and at the age of 10 succeeded his father King Zhuang of Chu, who was the Hegemon of China. However, in 575 BC King Gong was defeated by Chu's archrival Jin in the Battle of Yanling and Chu's power declined. He ruled for 31 years and was succeeded by his eldest son, King Kang of Chu. Three of King Gong's younger sons also ascended the throne, all by treacherous means.

Battle of Yanling

When King Gong ascended the throne in 590 BC Chu was the strongest power in China. In 597 BC his father King Zhuang defeated Chu's archrival Jin in the Battle of Bi and was recognized as the Hegemon by other states. However, King Gong's reign was marked by Chu's decisive defeat by the resurgent Jin in the 575 BC Battle of Yanling.

The battle was triggered by a series of minor events. In 577 BC, the Jin vassal state Zheng attacked the Chu vassal state Xu (許). The next year Chu attacked Zheng in revenge, and forced Zheng to switch its loyalty to Chu. Zheng then attacked Song, another Jin vassal state. In 575 BC, Duke Li of Jin raised an army to attack Zheng, while King Gong led the Chu army north to defend his new ally.

The two forces met at Yanling, and Jin defeated Chu by attacking its weaker flanks manned by the poorly trained Zheng and Dongyi soldiers. During the battle King Gong was shot in the eye by an arrow. Despite his wound, at the end of the day King Gong summoned the chief military commander Zifan to discuss the battle plan for the next day, but caught Zifan drunk. King Gong decided to retreat and Zifan later committed suicide.

Conflicts with Wu

While Chu was preoccupied with its rivalry with Jin, the formerly insignificant state of Wu began to rise to its east. In 598 BC, during King Zhuang's reign, Chu minister Wuchen (Duke of Shen) defected to Jin after a personal dispute with general Zifan. In 584 BC Wuchen went on a mission to Wu on behalf of Jin to establish an alliance between the two states. He brought along 100 charioteers who taught the Wu army to use chariots, and successfully incited Wu to revolt against Chu. The Wu king Shoumeng invaded Chu, annexed the Chu city of Zhoulai, and took over many tribes that had been loyal to Chu.

In 570 BC Chu general Zichong attacked Wu, reaching Mount Heng (in present-day Dangtu County) in Wu territory. However, Wu counterattacked and took the important Chu city of Jia. Zichong was blamed for the loss and died from an illness. For the ensuing seven decades Chu would be consumed by a series of at least ten wars or battles with Wu, culminating in the 506 BC Battle of Boju, when the Wu army would capture and destroy the Chu capital Ying.

Posthumous title

In 560 BC, when King Gong was dying from illness, he summoned his ministers and requested to be given the pejorative posthumous title of Ling (靈) or Li (厲), expressing shame for losing the Battle of Yanling and causing disgrace to the nation. The ministers agreed at his insistence, but after his death they instead gave him the title Gong, meaning "humbly reverent". The pejorative title King Ling was later given to King Gong's second son Xiong Wei, who would in 541 BC murder his nephew Jia'ao and usurp the throne.

Succession

King Gong had at least five sons, four of whom became king. When King Gong died in 560 BC, he was succeeded by his eldest son King Kang of Chu, who died in 545 BC after 15 years of reign and was succeeded by his son Xiong Yuan (posthumous title Jia'ao). Four years later King Gong's second son Prince Wei murdered Jia'ao and his two sons when he was ill, and usurped the throne. Prince Wei was later given the pejorative posthumous title King Ling of Chu.

In 529 BC when King Ling was on an expedition against the State of Xu, his three younger brothers staged a coup d'etat and killed his son Crown Prince Lu. Prince Bi, the third brother, ascended the throne (posthumous title Zi'ao), and the fourth brother Prince Zixi became the prime minister. When news of the coup reached King Ling's troops they abandoned him en masse, and in desperation King Ling killed himself.

However, Prince Qiji, the fifth brother, concealed the truth about King Ling's death from Zi'ao and Zixi. Instead, he pretended to be defeated by King Ling and said the king would soon return to the capital. Zi'ao and Zixi were so fearful that they both committed suicide; Zi'ao had been king for less than twenty days. Prince Qiji then ascended the throne and would come to be known as King Ping of Chu.
